Reviews.Title: Great Camera, Great Photos & Great Price!
Reviews.Author: Doctor A.
Reviews.Content: As an experienced DSLR photographer, I needed a small and simple do-all vacation camera that would work for both my wife and me. The Nikon L610 is a superb camera for its size and price and meets our needs perfectly. I suspect it will probably meet the needs of most casual photographers.The quality Nikkor glass lens provides crisp and accurate images. The 14x zoom range is appropriate for most hand-held shots. The manual pop-up flash has a bit more output than most point & shoots and offers nice illumination. AA alkaline batteries are relatively long lasting (for still photos without flash) and can be purchased easily anywhere in the world. Regarding camera setup, for the vast majority of our photos, I select the AUTO setting and adjust the ISO sensitivity to 125 and simply point and shoot. The photos are very sharp with vivid color and we are pleased with the results nearly every time.For what it's worth, in reading some of the critical reviews on digital cameras, it seems the problems most people have occur in three areas: (1) battery life, (2) memory speed, and (3) user familiarity. Many seasoned photographers know that AA alkaline batteries offer the advantages of reasonably long life, affordability and availability -- especially when traveling overseas. No chargers, no voltage issues, no waiting, just plug & play. For improved performance, I use non-rechargeable Energizer Lithium AA batteries in my L610. These offer hundreds of trouble-free shots and battery life virtually becomes a non-issue (about $6 for a 4-pack on Amazon). As to memory, my choice is the SanDisk Extreme Class 10. The high-speed data transfer rate this memory card offers is particularly important when shooting videos. The current price for a 32GB card is about $30 on Amazon (a 16GB card is about half this price).As to ISO sensitivity, nearly every technical analysis of digital cameras shows image quality noticably degrades at settings above ISO 200 (ironically, similar results occur with film speeds). Unless there is a specific need, such as extremely low light or fast-action photography, lower ISO settings will give most folks much better photos under a broad range of conditions. Lastly, there is a lot of technology packed in these little automatic cameras. Obviously, we are much better off reading the camera user manual and becoming comfortable with the features and functions of these gadgets. As the saying goes, it is better to light a candle than to curse the darkness.

Reviews.Title: The best point and shoot out there
Reviews.Author: Carolina Fan
Reviews.Content: As an experienced SLR user who's had his own darkrooms back in the dark ages, the L610 is the camera of choice to take along everywhere. Dr. A's review is mandatory reading.Having a an excellent camera which uses AA Lithium batteries is huge advantage for virtually all of us. Even the best rechargeable batteries on high end cameras- with twice the voltage, lose ~ 10 to 15% of their power a week.  Having an excellent AA camera means never having to plug your camera into the wall and always having ~ 200 full power shots without fail.There are several very compelling reasons to choose the Nikon L 610 over it's competitors that use AA Lithium batteries, such as the the Canon PowerShot SX 160 - both of which I own- and have used extensively.The optics on both are superb. Razor sharp pictures at all focal lengths and apertures.  The Canon does have many more, user adjustable "high end" features than the Nikon, but the Canon SX 160 is crippled by some serious flaws.The Nikon's 3" display is a brilliant, crystal clear 460,000 pixels versus the Canon's 230,000 pixels- which appears truly muddy and dim in comparison to the display on the L 610.The CMOS on the Nikon SX610 (which is the "film" on every shot) is much more sensitive in low light shots without a flash and produces noticeably brighter and sharper pics.  (Think taking pics of the baby, or a portrait with window light from your back.)The lag time between shots with the Nikon is also noticeably faster, because the Nikon has a "set up menu" option in it's circuitry for the type of AA you're using to select and use Lithium AAs.Recommendations on setting up the L 610, even for the novice: choose "Auto", not "Easy Auto" in the scene mode and set up your menu options THERE and leave the scene mode in "Auto" for virtually all of your shots.  The "Auto" menu also lets you turn OFF things you'll never want to use, such as the welcome screen, print date, AF assist beam, and, most of all, the killer of all clear pictures, digital zoom.Finding the PDF manual for L 160 from Nikon's site isn't easy. This may help:[...]Recommended accessories for the L610:1- Lithium 9x AA batteries from Energizer. These make the "battery issue" simply disappear. Two will last for well over 200 shots- yes, there is a one to two second lag time as the flash recharges. Shop for quality and expect to pay ~ $1.90 per. I've had good results from Brooklyn Battery Works and Photo Land NY.2- Memory Card- Get the best, a 16 gig San Disk Class 10 card with 45mb/Sec transfer rate. Greatly reduces lag time and this camera is set up for Class 10.  16gig capacity for ~ 2000 stills at full resolution or 32 gig if you're going to shoot movies.3- GGS 3" Optical Glass LCD screen protector- it's the best- but this is now a real moving target on Amazon.  Make sure you get the original  from GGS in the red and black retail package.4- Camera Strap- Inexplicably, Nikon gives you a camera with two strap connection points for a "neck strap", which you'll want, but ships only a one point "wrist strap".  Solve this by ordering the slim two point neck strap that Nikon supplies for similar cameras: the Nikon AN-CP-23 strap. It's an extra $11 well spent.Search it on Amazon.5- Replacement USB cable- Confirmed by the tech staff at Mediabridge- the supplied Nikon UC-E6 cable is a Mini B with 8 pins- NOT the 5 pins found on every currently available aftermarket mini B. As of 9-03-13, the only replacement cable that works with the L 610- or any of it's Power Shot cameras- is the OEM Nikon UC-E6. Hold off buying any replacement cable for Nikon Power Shots until Mediabridge give us the right one-the mini B with 8 pins, not 5- they're working on it and they're the best.5- Camera Case- Tamrac makes the best cases- period. The Tamrac model 5292 fits the L610 perfectly and gives you room for 4 extra lithium AAs, the USB cable and extra memory cards. It's also just tall enough for you to tuck in your aftermarket Nikon neck strap.Enjoy.

Reviews.Title: Good camera - but a few small drawbacks
Reviews.Author: James F. Kadlec "JFK"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera based on the pre-release reviews the first day it was available.  I have now used it for several months, having taken vacation pictures as well as random shots, both scenic and casual shots of people.On the positive side, the camera is really well thought out, fits nicely in the hand, feels substantial and has relatively intuitive adjustments. On the negative side is it consumes batteries at a terrific rate.Since I really bought the camera for vacation, I was pleased that it would take AA alkaline batteries, however when using it with alkaline batteries it didn't take long to learn that it goes through them at a very rapid pace.  I was not getting anywhere near the number of images suggested by the reviewers.  During a busy day with a lot of shots, I would go through a set of alkaline batteries.  I just wound up buying a lot of batteries during the vacation.Since returning home, I have gone to the rechargeable NiCads and it seems to give me more images with these.  When you change battery types though, you must use the menu to reset the camera to the appropriate batteries, apparently to maximize the lifespan.  Something I don't like though, is that every time that you take out the memory card to put some pictures into your laptop or PC, the batteries fall out.  It is an annoyance.  The card itself takes some getting used to in that you really have to push it way down to get it to click into place.The zoom is very responsive............I mean very responsive.  I have no complaint about the zoom itself, but adjusting it is so sensitive that you cannot tighten up the field with people shots.  You either get them too small in the image or you cut them off.  A slower zoom would be so much better so that you can have more control.  Even though I am much more familiar with the camera now, the zoom is still way too touchy for small increments.One real complaint I do have about the camera, is that it is slow on recovery of the flash, and with the other cameras I have had, if I were trying to take a flash picture, and waiting for the flash to recover, I could hold the shutter release down and as soon as the flash had recovered, the next image would be taken immediately.  With this camera, you must release the shutter button and depress it again for the next flash picture.  Of course, this means that you are guessing when the flash has recovered before taking the next picture.The final thing is one on which I made my own mistake.  I find that having a real compact camera I can put into my pocket is very important to me.  This one is too large for that.  While this camera is quite small, it isn't small enough to put into your pocket.  It will fit into a purse, but not a pocket.  Whereas I used to carry a small pocket camera much more, because I never knew when I would get a shot, this one must be taken along when I am anticipating using it.Overall, I really like this camera and would recommend it to others.  It is a nice design, and perhaps none of what I consider as drawbacks may be important to others.  I will keep it as an adjunct camera, but I am still going to buy a different compact which will really fit into my pocket, but which has a longer zoom than my present Sony.

Reviews.Title: Nikon Coolpix L610 Camera: Solid Camera with a little Know-How
Reviews.Author: NewsView
Reviews.Content: The Nikon Coolpix L610 is what I would call a "best value" travel-zoom camera with a strong lens, a decent selection of scene modes and accurate color representation. I suspect it could use a firmware update to deal with metering/motion blur issues some users are reporting (in low light the shutter tends to slow down, resulting in camera shake or subject-motion blur). With a steady hand it takes good pictures under both bright and low light. The flash is very good in that it does not create that pinpoint glare that small camera flashes often do. The flash can also extend nearly 20', better than average. The caveat is that because the flash is a pop-up it is easy to miss the small blinking indicator suggesting that flash is necessary due to inadequate light.Short battery life is the most oft-reported consumer complaint. Sure enough, the included AA alkaline batteries died within 40 pictures; supposedly I should have been able to obtain about 120. With rechargeable batteries (3000mAh) I obtained roughly 160 photos per charge (but it could be that the rechargeable batteries were too old). The camera went from far below average to excellent once I switched to Lithium AA batteries. I took the camera on a trip with a set of lithium batteries, took some 400 photos, and returned home with the battery icon still reading fully charged (I wouldn't be surprised if I manage to get 500-600 pictures using lithium AA batteries). Changing batteries takes an otherwise poor performer and pushes it into better-than-average territory. (TIP: There is a menu setting for battery type that you must select before you change from the default alkaline type.) On a final note about the battery, I did have one incidence early on while I was still using alkaline batteries where I noticed the battery icon had gone down by half. When the LCD preview image and the lens simultaneously stuck with the batteries fully exhausted a few minutes later, I realized that a half-battery icon essentially means that it is time to change out the batteries on the spot (the icon really ought to be more specific).Image quality can range from okay (somewhat overexposed) to outstanding depending on the light, taking the time to pre-focus and the steadiness of one's hand. In general, the Nikon Coolpix L610 camera is best for still shots. Particularly impressive is the fact that the 14x zoom lens also functions at a mere 1cm for close-up macro photography. I would have no qualms recommending this camera for people who sell on Ebay as a result of its strong macro performance. The Nikon Coolpix L610 camera is also good for people (portrait shots and close-up images with flash). It serves well for landscapes, handling harsh lighting conditions very well (the 14x zoom is also travel-friendly). With a particularly steady hand or a tripod, this camera also excels in low light. (I have an Olympus SLR from some years back that does not perform nearly as well in low light as this camera in spite of a larger sensor. That being said, subject matter in low light must not be moving or there will be motion blur. If that's an issue, I recommend owners to make a regular habit of popping up the flash while indoors or outdoors at dusk/dawn.)There are tradeoffs at this price point and being a tad slow is one of them. Consequently, this camera is not the best pick for hasty snapshots of sports, kids and pets. It's not so much shutter lag at issue. The main issue for fast-action photography is the delay in writing (processing) images to the SD card (a delay that only increases when the flash needs time to recycle). The good news? Image write-speed can be significantly improved using a newer class 10 SD card of at least 30mbs of transfer speed (a faster card will also improve movie-recording).The Nikon Coolpix L610 powers up and is ready for photo taking in under 2 seconds. If, however, the camera goes into sleep mode it takes considerably longer to wake it up. Another gripe I have is that the screen will go off after a user-set amount of time but there is no way to control when the lens retracts. It will remain "at ready" for three minutes, even after the screen goes to sleep. I think that's a recipe for eventually knocking the lens off kilter (and perhaps why Nikon apparently gets complaints of lens errors on some of their cameras). My other digital cameras retracted the lens after about 30-45 seconds of inactivity, and the screen after about a minute. For best results, I recommend keeping this camera in a camera bag when not in use. (I also recommend replacing the hand strap because it is surprisingly thin and not up to the quality of a typical hand strap.) Similarly, like most camera LCD screens this one seems a bit more exposed without the rim around it that was common to older digital cameras. To avoid scratches and dings, it would probably be best to cover it with a screen protector. In bright light, the LCD has about average readability. (I have never found a digital camera view screen that fares well in bright sun.)The L610's menu options are easy enough to figure out without a manual, even though this is my first time owning a Nikon-brand digital camera. The ergonomics of this camera, with its gracefully curved lines, are better than average. Although the camera is a bit larger than some, the rubberized hand-grip is comfortable and the weight of the AA batteries actually helps dampen handshake. (I would say this camera is purse-size but not pocket size.) The battery compartment, like many cameras these days, is located under the same door that the SD card uses. The battery door is a bit flimsy in feel and I have my doubts that it will hold up over many years but overall the camera has a solid feel. (Like most plastic cameras, I wouldn't expect the body to survive a drop to a hard floor, however.)Operationally, AUTO mode produces inconsistent image quality compared to self-selecting the appropriate scene mode or leaving the camera in Easy mode (the default). In easy/simple mode the camera self-selects from among six of the 18 scene options. I also found that because the camera doesn't know what you intend to shoot it takes less time to focus if the multipoint AF is turned off in favor of the center-weight (single) auto focus brackets. Similarly, it is important to leave the "motion detection" function enabled (a green icon lights up when a subject moves).  As for image quality, I note some mild corner softening of images, particularly branches in the upper left corner. Inexplicably, sometimes something in the picture at the same distance/depth appears more crisp whereas an adjacent aspect of the picture goes noticeably softer (in landscape scene mode of a still subject where motion blur is not an issue). I also note that for sunny outdoor scenes, particularly photos with white objects/animals, it is best to use the exposure compensation, reducing exposure by about 1/3. (The nice thing about exposure compensation on this camera is that it remains locked in until you change it.)Video is recorded in HD although only digital zoom is available during filming. This does not pose a problem, in my opinion, because on cameras where optical zoom is permitted there tends to be mechanical lens noises in the audio. Movie quality is decent, although it rips through memory card space and batteries due to the 16MP/HD content. Owners should also be aware that unless one owns a newer computer with a current-generation video card, playback of HD video will be choppy if not impossible.All in all, I would say this camera is a great value for the money. The bad rap this camera has received by some may stem from the ease of forgetting to pop up the manual flash to enable a faster shutter speed when shooting indoors under poor light. The second and even more common complaint surrounds alkaline battery life. Nikon could have remedied the poor first impression by packaging the camera with lithium AA batteries for a vastly improved experience. Still, it's nice to know there are a few AA battery cameras left. No matter where one travels, AA batteries can be found in a pinch.

Reviews.Title: Great overall experience
Reviews.Author: V. Jaquery
Reviews.Content: If you do most of your photography with DSLR & interchangeable lenses, point & shoot cameras do take some adjusting. For travel we've had different 'wafer sized' cameras...then upgraded last year to a mid-range point & shoot from another manufacturer. But programming/settings were not intuitive. In that same range, this Coolpix L610 competes well. Settings & programming are more intuitive to us and after 200 photos this camera feels right, though we're still taking it through its paces. Rechargeable batteries are a must as this is a high drain device. We purchased a kit/package that exceeded our expectations regarding quality (mini-tripod, case, rechargeable batteries/charger/European adapter, 16g SD card).

Reviews.Title: Battery life for the L610
Reviews.Author: Putt
Reviews.Content: Doc A. thanks for the good review. Very helpful. I looked for a point and shoot camera for my wife for quite some time, and truthfully, even with camera's costing nearly 300 dollars there was the same type of basic problems with battery life, quality, features etc. The L610 for 140 dollars had much of the upper end featured point and shoot camera's features and I believe is an excellent buy. I read one review where a lady complained about motion with blurry photo's trying to take pictures of her active children. I read Doc A comments on setting the ISO to 125, but i played with this and ultimately set it to the highest settings which nearly eliminated the blurr's and the picture still looks good to my old eyes. Normally though i set the ISO to 'Auto' and just use the 'Auto' setting like Doc A. Just point and shoot. You get a good pic everytime. IF I want to minimize the blurr's i just crank up the ISO to max and get great pic's.This brings me to my review. Battery life. I almost took this camera back as i had the same experience that many did. Put in a pair of alkaline's and i get about 20-30 pic's. Put in a pair of rechargeables and i get not a bunch more. Try to take a video of 2 minutes and the batteries are toast in an instant. It was almost unbearable. AGAIN i read Doc A's review and tried lithium batteries. The only one's they had in the store the day i went to buy were the 9x ultimate Energizers for 8.99 for 4. My report is this. I have taken 600+ hundred pictures and several short video's up to 5 minutes, several of those in addition to the 600 pic's and my batteries are still reading FULL. Every upper end point and shoot camera i looked at, being fare, i should say 90 percent of everyone i tried, required the power of a lithium type battery or equivalent. Whether it was a Canon, Sony etc people complained about the short battery life of their cameras. As the camera has less features the longer the battery lasts. No way around it. Even buying the batteries from the store shelf at 8.99 (you could get them cheaper on Amazon)is not much more than a latte if you split that in half 4.50 for two. Two batteries i have been taking these 600+ pictures for a month now with still a full reading on the battery charge using flash where needed and some short videos. My son has the smaller L26 Nikon and it will run fairly long on just a pair of alkalines, but not this camera. Buy lithium. They will last a month easily and if you don't take too many pictures they will last a few months if you take only a couple of hundred pictures per month. There are 6x lithium's cheaper even. Like between 5.99 and 6.99 for 4. I have not tried those so i cannot comment, but those will be my next try..

Reviews.Title: Great vacation pictures
Reviews.Author: Sarah Carpenter
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera on a whim right before taking a family vacation--boy am I glad I did!  We took 890 pictures (on one set of lithium AAs)and only a very few of them are out of focus or blurry--a miracle with my overactive kids!  The flash has to be raised manually, but the camera can take excellent pictures in auto mode with very little light--very nice low light pictures compared to previous cameras I have had--so that gives you a choice.  Ocassionally the focus would set to something other than what I wanted to focus on, so it takes a little learning to use it to best effect.  I did not like the easy auto mode and didn't feel the pictures using it were great, but the regular auto mode worked well, and we took lots of great macro photos (you can't use the macro in easy auto either).  I used the beach scene setting for the beach and was very happy with it.  Great color on the shots.  I also liked that the focus was good even at full zoom, so no more blurry shots at full zoom.  There are a couple of oddities on the camera ... it would have been nice if the card was accessible without opening the battery compartment, as not only do the batteries scatter when you open it, but the battery door is bigger and harder to open and close than the little card doors.  I tried using a cord, but the cord door was also somewhat difficult and I decided I'd rather just take the card out.  You will need to buy a card separate.  There is a little recovery time when you zoom, and after using the flash, but I didn't find either to be a problem.  The screen is clear enough to tell if you have a good shot when you take it. I like the way it feels to hold as well, no slip, easy controls.  I'm very very happy with the camera and with the snapshots we got!  Easy, great shots.

Reviews.Title: Better than I expected
Reviews.Author: NJ Contributor "Eddie"
Reviews.Content: As a former Canon user, I'm very impressed with the crisp pictures this camera is able to produce.I received my camera from Amazon the same day my niece was having her 3rd birthday.I didn't have time to test all features but I know to increase my ISO for indoors/low light conditions.With that said, I prefer low ISO settings for sharp pictures and the camera's lowest ISO setting is 125.My first pictures were taken under this setting and while they came out sharp, they were a bit dark.I increased my ISO to 200 and WOW, pictures were perfect!.With my old Canon (A540), I had to use ISO 400 for pictures to be barely viewable.A day after, I had time to play around with different ISO settings and Scenes and foundISO 400 also produces nice sharp pictures so I will use that setting on future indoor/low light conditions.I recommend staying away from any pre-defined scene setting and use Auto with ISO setting 200-400 for indoors and ISO 125 for outdoors.Additionally, get yourself a lithium battery and make sure to change the setting under the menu to reflect the battery in use.I found using regular alkaline batteries, it would last around 40-50 shots and the flash takes some time to load.With lithium battery, flash loads instantly between shots.This camera is smaller than my previous Canon A540 and fits nicely on my jean front pockets.Personally, I love the design and received many compliments. I'm not a fan of flat cameras.Overall, I'm very happy with my purchase and Amazon's delivery was prompt - as always.Update: 12/28/2013I'm not sure if the camera had dropped but I'm unable to fully close the battery compartment.Now, I have to purchase a new camera just under one year of use. BTW, going back to Canon.I understand I'm within the year warranty but I rather avoid the hassle.Knocking down 2 stars (from 5 to 3) for lack of durability.

Reviews.Title: Good point & shoot
Reviews.Author: trigchance
Reviews.Content: I took this camera on my vacation to China & I shot 2700 photos with it(over a three week period).  The photos were all sharp, clear with excellent, accurate color.  I did not use the video functions, so I will reserve comment on that function until I try it.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Point and Shoot
Reviews.Author: cinemaniak "cinemaniak"
Reviews.Content: No complaints about battery life. Compared off-brand Alkaline AA batteries (which lasted about 50 exposures) with Sanyo Eneloop 2,000mAh Rechargeable Ni-MH batteries (500+ exposures over three days before recharging again). Battery life great! Pics great for this type of camera (4 stars). Nightime (handheld) Scene mode fantastic. Got great shots at 1100 ISO and 1/8th of a second. No blurring and minimal noise. Very impressed. Great wideangle and enough zoom. Love it!

Reviews.Title: Coolpix L610 Zoom Test
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer

I wanted to show the zoom capability so I took several sequence pics and then took a movie of them. The bird object is actually in the shade and I'm standing about 25 yards away. Cannot believe how detailed at the closest range on the zoom. As far as the batteries go I'm using Engergizer Ultimate Lithiums and it is no problem. The video is taken from my laptop with the video mode of the camera.

Reviews.Title: A pretty sweet camera (UPDATED!)
Reviews.Author: jahshel
Reviews.Content: This is a nice little digital camera, and with the wide angle lens, it takes amazing photos. I really cannot complain, the list of features and the quality are amazing, and the price was more than fair, considering the original list price.One caveat:This does film in full HD (and it looks amazing), BUT if your computer is older or just doesn't have the right video card, it will have a problem processing the HD. In other words, I can film amazing videos in full HD and it looks great when I play it back on the camera, but when I try to watch the videos on my desktop with Win XP, the video and the audio turn out choppy and slow. I tried playing videos on my 3-year-old netbook with Win 7, same exact thing. Then I did some research and found out that it's because both my machines have older graphics cards that can't handle HD.I found out this was a pretty common problem for a lot of people.So, I'm hanging on to it, but still have to wait for that new computer eventually. Until then, I can down-convert the videos, or just film videos in lower quality (which still isn't bad quality either). All in all, it's a high-quality camera and I would recommend it to the more-than-occasional photographer.(UPDATE! 7-30-13)Well, I dropped the star level on this review, because after vacationing with this camera, the one thing that irritates me to no end is the fact that it goes through batteries like they're going out of style. It takes two AA's, and if you're filming in HD or photographing at the highest quality, you might have an hour or two (and that's pushing it!) of battery life.I wish this thing came with a rechargeable lithium battery like my older Nikon. I really don't understand why it doesn't. It seems like using standard batteries is a major step backwards for this sort of camera--especially because this camera is higher-end compared to my older Nikon. :(That said, I finally got a newer computer and the HD video does look amazing once you've got a machine that can process it.

Reviews.Title: Very Poor Quality
Reviews.Author: Mr. M
Reviews.Content: Had to return.  As long as the zoom was not used it focused great.  As soon as the zoom was used it would not focus on the subject. Just before the picture was captured, it went out of focus.  I had to turn off and on to have it focus right again (without zooming).  I am user of Nikon D700 with pro glass.  I am not used to such poor quality from Nikon.  I ended up purchasing a Sony HX30V instead.  It might have been a little more costly but it if focuses like a charm.

Reviews.Title: There are better choices for the amateur photographer.
Reviews.Author: TCrow
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera based on Nikon's reputation.  It does take very good low-light pictures, so if this is your goal, this camera is a good choice.  As far as a simple-to-use point and shoot camera, there are much better choices out there.  I found alkaline batteries are drained much too quickly so if you choose this camera, lithium batteries are a must.  The camera is very slow to process a photo after it is taken--too slow for my taste.  I've also had trouble with blurry photos and poor exposure.  I want a camera that is truly "point and shoot" and "easy to use" which this camera is not.  Finally it is quite big and heavy.  I regret purchasing this camera.

Reviews.Title: Too Slow, Drains Batteries, Blurry Pics
Reviews.Author: K.L.T. "Mommy of 2"
Reviews.Content: I am not a camera expert. But I played with this camera in a store and thought it was nice so I purchased it. I used it for over a week and found that it was incredibly slow, constantly drained the double A batteries and most of the photos were blurry. I have a 3 month old baby and a toddler. If the baby smiled and I grabbed the camera, by the time I was able to turn it on and take a pic, she was no longer smiling. It also takes a while to process in between photos. If I took one of my toddler and wanted to take another you have to wait several seconds while it processed. Most of the photos were blurry. I played around and tried every setting in every situation and was rarely pleased with the photo. I returned the camera for a full refund and purchased a different camera. I do not recommend anyone with kids that wants an easy camera purchase this one. On a positive note - I liked the way it fits in your hand and it has some cool effects within the camera. But you cannot change the effect once you have taken the pic.

Reviews.Title: Lens error
Reviews.Author: tigger
Reviews.Content: The lens will stick and refuse to focus shortly after the warrenty is up.  A short google search shows that this is a common problem.  The cost to fix is more than the purchase price of the camera. Good camera until the warrenty runs out.  Reviews done immediately after recieving the camera would not reflect this issue.

Reviews.Title: Big Disappointment - Save Your Money
Reviews.Author: cmac101
Reviews.Content: Dear Potential Camera Buyers,I can only say that I am extremely disappointed in this camera.  I have always been a big fan of nikon cameras.  The reasons I bought this camera were that it fit in my hand like it was meant to be there.  The size of the camera fit in my coat pocket so I could take it to football games and not notice it was there. The features and ease of use are outstanding but I need a camera I can count on to take a quality picture every time.  I take pictures at group events on a regular basis. The picture quality is poor and blurry pictures are the norm.  I called nikon for help and they told me to use the auto mode, not the easy auto mode and put the ISO to 150, that did not help.  Than I took pictures with my old SonyCyber Shot, my wife's Canon PowerShot SD1200IS, and a Fuji FinePix 4.1 mp and put them into iphoto for comparisons.  Needless to say my old Sony was the best followed by the PowerShot, FinePix, and finally the L610 which was a distant last.  I hope to trade this camera in on a Canon A1400 powershot with and optical viewfinder and hopefully that will meet my needs. I will let you know.  Again, I am sorry to disappoint you but save your money and buy another camera.

Reviews.Title: Great ccmera-great price.
Reviews.Author: K. Corrigan
Reviews.Content: Recently purchased and used extensively during a trip to Bermuda.  Camera performed very well in various lighting conditions utilizing the auto and scene modes. Pictures are clear and sharp.  I've noticed much talk of poor battery performance--I've installed one set of Lithium batteries and to this point have taken over 250 pictures and still going.  Make sure to change battery type to Lithium in the setttings menu.  I purchased refurbished from cameta camera and unit is like new. Highly recommended-both camera and store.

Reviews.Title: Convenient and easy to use camera
Reviews.Author: William Hamilton
Reviews.Content: Photo quality is excellent, especially telephoto pictures.  Telephotos with other cameras I tried tended to be fuzzy because of a very mild tremor in my hands.  This one gives very sharp pictures.  Movies are especially good.  My only dissatisfactions are with the high price and low magnification (5x).  Having a paper instructional manual rather than a CD is another plus.

Reviews.Title: Good but quirky
Reviews.Author: A. Schmuland "Arlene S"
Reviews.Content: I've had the camera for several months and I keep the camera with me more so than perhaps most people would (I live in AK, you never know when you're going to see a moose or some other wonderful wildlife.) It's almost always in my shoulderbag and I'm not particularly protective of it--the screen has a few scratches/cracks and that's because I don't keep it in a case but just let it rattle around in the bottom of my bag. The quality of images is excellent for size & price point. It's not significantly bigger than the other point & shoots I've had and the quality definitely makes up for the size difference. It's easy to use. The 14x zoom is really nice for the size/price of the camera. However the differential in the zoom speed is weird--it goes fast (really touchy, I see others have said this) up to about 3/4 of the way and then it moves extremely slow--it even stops at that 3/4 point and you have to keep holding the zoom to get it to go further, even when it appears to no longer be zooming in. Since I'm not always looking at the details of the display as opposed to what I'm trying to view through the display, I haven't always taken the zoom in as far as I would have preferred. Battery life got a whole lot longer when I picked up some Sony rechargeable high capacity batteries--a considerable difference from the alkaline, in my view. However, transferring the photos to my laptop has proven challenging. Using the USB cable simply does not work. My Mac does not recognize that anything is on the other end of that cable, no matter what I do. So I have to pull out the card and plug it into the slot on the Mac. This isn't a huge challenge normally (it even further extends battery life if I'm transferring direct from card rather than cable) but what I've run into is because I've so consistently opened the battery cover door, more so than would be required for battery replacement, the closures/locks on the battery cover have now given way. I can close the door and lock it if I have no batteries in, but if the batteries are in, the pressure they put on the door makes it spring open. Since it's nearly impossible to keep steady hands while keeping pressure on the battery compartment door, I've had to tape it shut and then tape/retape as I want to transfer photos. Judging by some of the other reviews, this is happening to more than a few of us and Nikon should be considering this as a defect of the engineering, not ours to fix.To sum up: great quality pics and zoom for size/price of camera. It's a point & shoot, don't expect a professional level camera. Battery door is a giant pain so if you decide to go with this one make sure you a) get high capacity rechargeable batteries and can b) transfer images via cable as much as possible so you don't wear out the door connections as quickly as I did. If it helps, I am looking at replacing it with the same exact model since I really like how it photographs over any other point & shoot I've had, but I'll be changing some of my behavior with the next one.

Reviews.Title: Great little camera!
Reviews.Author: L. Simms "Pokemom"
Reviews.Content: I love, love, love this camera. As a scrapbooker I insist on a portable camera that will fit in my pocket. Although it's a little on the large size, it still fits in my pocket. I don't need the highest quality photos just something to record the moment, so I was pleasantly surprised at the detail and clarity of the pictures. For a point-and-shoot camera it takes great pictures, much better quality than my old Kodak camera. It does need battery replacement often, but I'm using alkaline batteries right now(make sure you carry extras!). I'll have to invest in some lithium AAs.

Reviews.Title: Nice little camera!
Reviews.Author: Medimundo
Reviews.Content: My wife's the photographer in our family, but I needed a camera for my own modest needs.  After a couple of weeks' use, both she and I are duly impressed by the quality of the L610's images and its overall performance.  At first, however, I did have a bit of buyer's remorse when--after buying the camera-- I read some of the reviews on Amazon complaining about how quickly the AA batteries become depleted.  My remorse increased as I had the same experience with the alkaline AA batteries supplied with the camera as well as with other unused alkaline AA batteries we had on hand.  I then did some research online on AA batteries and as a result purchased four rechargeable Eneloop Pro Ni-MH AA batteries ($16.80) plus a HiTech Smart Quick Charger ($11.99).  What a difference!  Just returned from a 12-day vacation, took about 200 photos plus a little video, and the little indicator shows that there's still about 50% left on the original pair of batteries.  In summary, I'm very pleased with my L610.

Reviews.Title: Perfect for my needs
Reviews.Author: Christian Hartley
Reviews.Content: So I bought this camera because I needed a better camera than I had to record family outings in Alaska.  I thought about buying a bigger more loaded camera, but my need was strictly for family photos and so I stayed in this price range.  This camera fit that bill, plus some.  I also use it at my job at a fire department to record information on calls for the fire reports.  Pictures are high quality, not grainy at all, and the flash works very intuitively.  I put a 32gb chip into it, and it will take 1,818 photos or :28 minutes of video.  Perfect for my needs, and very much higher quality than I expect for such a hand-sized camera.

Reviews.Title: Nice Camera
Reviews.Author: Goldielocks512
Reviews.Content: We got this for my daughter for Christmas.  It is a really nice camera, takes great pictures, and looks and feels nice.  I would like one for myself. :)

Reviews.Title: Great little camera
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: What an awesome little red gem! Don't believe the battery life issues. If you use lithium batteries it lasts a great long time. Takes awesome photos and video in a small compact camera. I am sure there are better ones out there, but for the price of this camera, the small size, what a great camera taking great photos--I wanted simple, point shoot and get great shots, and this is what I got with this awesome camera.

Reviews.Title: Nikon Coolpix L610 Camera
Reviews.Author: Herb Hutchinson
Reviews.Content: I chose this camera because of its 14x Zoom capability. Photos I have recently taken using that zoom capability are outstanding.

Reviews.Title: Great camera, but somewhat slow battery recovery after using flash
Reviews.Author: Tamie
Reviews.Content: Takes several seconds for batteries to recover after using flash.  Otherwise, a great camera.  Very fast turn on for instant use.

Reviews.Title: Economical with Quality Images and HD Video
Reviews.Author: Scott D. Welch
Reviews.Content: When my Nikon Coolpix L22 was lost, I needed to find a replacement as I carry a point and shoot with me virtually all of the time, but especially when visiting historical sites or museums as some/most do not permit the use a DSLR but will allow the use of point and shoot cameras (without flash). The other primary reason was to have a small portable unit with Full HD (high definition) 1080p video capability. I had looked at many models, including other brands, and almost went with the Nikon COOLPIX P510 due to the extra zoom power, but decided on the L610 as a smaller size for increased portability (i.e., I can wear it on my belt in a pouch or in a jacket pocket) was the deciding factor.The amount of technology built in to these small cameras is amazing and the quality of the of L610 images is typical Nikon, excellent in pretty much all cases, with sharp, and colorful output. With 16MP at full resolution, enlargements look fantastic. I do have a 16x20 canvas print hanging in my house from my L610. One must keep in mind that in an "extremely" low light setting and when zooming the aperture will likely be at the f/5.8 range and results may not be that great. However, when not zoomed, or zoomed very little, and nearer f/3.1, the quality is very good.There are setting and mode selections for virtually any type of photography, such as museums (quiet no click, no flash), portraits, close-up, landscape and others, and all of them deliver very high quality images. Nikon's optical VR (Vibration Reduction) image stabilizing feature works pretty much as well as with my DSLRs meaning that a slight camera shake should not ruin a photo. As a note, the Auto setting works extremely well in most circumstances.I use Non-rechargeable Energizer Advanced Lithium AA Batteries and while I have never really counted the number of shots I get, I would estimate, with and without flash, at least 400-500, maybe more. A SanDisk Extreme 16 GB SDHC Class 10 card provides up to 2,000 full resolution still images. For video mode, a 32GB would be best.For my purposes, as outlined above, I have never been disappointed and definitely recommend this point and shoot Nikon offering. The 5 star rating is for a point and shoot, and not compared to all camera offerings, such as against a DSLR.

Reviews.Title: Great Shot
Reviews.Author: Antoinette
Reviews.Content: This is an easy to understand camera, takes great pictures with little help from me.  I enjoy taking pictures just to remember where I have been - this camera makes it easy and I don't have to be an expert picture taker, it does it all.

Reviews.Title: Good Deal for the Money
Reviews.Author: T. Parker
Reviews.Content: Like it not the easiest camera to use - read the instructions. It uses regular AA batteries. My only complaint is that the battery life is poor. Low light photos are fantastic and the price was right. A great value for the money, if on vacation, or if you are shooting all day make sure you have spare batteries.

Reviews.Title: Perfect for my needs
Reviews.Author: Cookie Jar
Reviews.Content: I wanted a simple, point-and-shoot to replace my defunct Kodak Easy Share LS443.  After reading several reviews of this and another camera, I chose this L610.  I've had it for two months now and have used it some and it's all that I wished it to be.  Easy to use and takes great pictures of family, outings, kids' sports, etc.  Software is a pleasure compared to the old Kodak Easy Share software, which was never easy or intuitive for me.  I'm not a professional photographer, just a weekend, picture-taking grandpa and this camera does it for me at a good price.

Reviews.Title: The perfect camera for us
Reviews.Author: Michelle Stambaugh
Reviews.Content: We recently purchased this camera as an upgrade from the one we had. We are very impressed how clear the pictures are. Just for fun, we zoomed in as far as we could and took a picture of the house at the end of our street. It came in perfectly clear. As far as battery life, so far no problems. We purchased Eneloop rechargeable batteries at the same time as the camera. We take a lot of pictures with just having a baby and have not even needed to recharge once.

Reviews.Title: Great price.  Great simple little camera
Reviews.Author: Masako Wada
Reviews.Content: Great little camera.  We love it. Simple to operate, and small enough to carry around.  Reasonable price as well.  Takes pretty good video as well.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera for the price
Reviews.Author: Patrick Doyle
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera in January of 2013 and it has turned out to be an excellent camera. For $150 you get a very useful 14x zoom and a clear 16 megapixels. It takes great shots outside and inside it has decent low light performance. The flash is very good as well. It is nicely sized for being a megazoom camera. Unfortunately, the battery life is hysterically low and you can only take a short video or about 60 pictures on alkaline battery's. I recommend rechargeables. Also, I have had a small issue with the shutter flaps. Occasionally it only opens part way. Also, the camera doesn't like to focus on close up low light conditions. But other than these niggles this camera takes ultra clear shots and is a great all round multipurpose camera that is easy to understand and operate.

Reviews.Title: Nice but not great
Reviews.Author: Crysania Weese
Reviews.Content: first of the battery life on this camera is horrible. But if you use lithium batteries they will last a lot longer. the zoom on the camera is fantastic and so is the macro function or close up. I would recommend this camera to anyone seeking a inexpensive digital camera. It is well worth the money.

Reviews.Title: Great camera that's easy to use, but devours batteries and don't, forget there's no memory card.
Reviews.Author: JSII
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera about a month ago. It is very easy to use right out of the box. It has great features like being able to take close-up, wide angle, panoramic and zoom photos. There are many easy selections on the digital screen for indoor, outdoor, bright sun, low light and many other conditions. The camera fits easily in your hand and is light weight. Pictures come out beautiful and transferring them to your computer and/printer is simple via the enclose USB cable. There is also a cable provided for non-USB connection to older equipment.Now for the bad news. This camera uses up standard AA batteries so fast that I will be getting rechargeable batteries for this camera. Definitely purchase a case that can hold the camera and extra batteries.Also, the camera does not come with a memory card so order it at the same time as the camera. Otherwise you'll only get about 5-8 photo images or 2 panaramic images before you'll need to export them in order to capture more. There are excellent deals available on Amazon for memory cards. I got 64GB for under $35.All things considered, I love this camera (It's that good) and have chosen to keep it because of its versatility, image quality and light weight. Smart phones and tablets take good photos. This camera takes GREAT photos. Get this camera. Take some photos. Make your own comparison. I'm certain you'll agree.

Reviews.Title: Got tape?
Reviews.Author: Bob Lewis
Reviews.Content: I've used cameras nearly all my life, and that's a long time. I've had everything from an 8x10 view camera to a Canon F1n with medium format equipment in between. This is my second Nikon digital and probably my last. The 1st Nikon decided to drain the rechargeable battery without the camera being used. This one, the L610 seems to be total junk. While on vacation the battery compartment opened and dropped the batteries on the ground. Thank you. Try as I might, the batter compartment would not stay closed until I taped the door shut. Also, after the power being interrupted, the camera began to behave erratically and then stopped working. The next day I turned it on and it worked okay, but of course the battery door is still taped shut and the way this thing eats batteries it is not a minor inconvenience.

Reviews.Title: Not a fan
Reviews.Author: A. Gonzalez
Reviews.Content: Usually I spend weeks reviewing cameras before I purchase them but my mother needed a camera and I only had a short time to help her decide.  I went with this model based on some of the fantastic reviews but I wish I had a chance to play around with the camera before purchasing.  I did get special batteries and it has increased battery performance, I have no complaints there.  My complaints are in any picture in low light or with moving targets (i.e. kids).  It is difficult to get a good picture if your subjects are not completely still (and how many kids can stay completely still for a picture?). I also don't like that the flash doesn't pop up automatically when you need a flash.  How is that not automatic with today's technology?  For the price it's a good camera if you want it mainly to shoot outdoor landscapes in good light.  I would not recommend it for anything else.

Reviews.Title: Holding my Breath
Reviews.Author: DENNIS LOVETT
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera for my Granddaughter as a Christmas gift. She loved it and everything worked fine. Until, after about 5 weeks the flash quit working. The camera still took  pictures, until the flash was needed.I contacted Nikon who told me to return the camera to where I had purchased it. Of course we had the camera long enough to have been past the Amazon return policy date.I contacted Amazon by email and they agreed to exchange the camera and sent me a return shipping label.I had the replacement camera in two days.So far it is working fine.

Reviews.Title: Pictures out of focus
Reviews.Author: Mrs. S. M. Thompson
Reviews.Content: We bought this camera because of the good reviews it had. Unfortunately it does not live up to them. The camera looks nice, is easy to handle and easy to use. The problem is the quality of the images. When taking a view shot the outlines of houses, hills etc are not clearly defined. On close up shots, for example trees or plants, the images are blurred. I have had discussions with Nikon but they say that the camera is taking pictures within specification. I have spent the last four years taking pictures using a blackberry phone and this provided photos better that the nikon. A big disappointment I expected better from Nikon.

Reviews.Title: Love This Camera!
Reviews.Author: Cobra79
Reviews.Content: I was looking to upgrade my point and shoot digital camera.  I saw this model in a local store and liked the size, weight and overall feel & features.  They had no more in stock and lucky for me I found this on Amazon for a cheaper price.  I have a more expensive DSLR camera, but wanted a more compact one also to take with me when the larger camera would be too much.  Took it to a college basketball game and the photos came out clear, considering I was in the nosebleed section, and I could zoom in and almost see the coach writing a play on his board, and the pictures were so sharp.  So far I am not disappointed in the pictures and the red color is really sharp looking (not a fire engine red, but more of a maroon color).  There are a lot of scene choices to pick from if you want to get a more custom shot.  The sports mode worked great for the basketball game and the shots all came out clear.

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: Corinav
Reviews.Content: This camera is a great buy! Though I didn't buy it through Amazon, thought I'd still write a review for the Amazon users! It takes clear pictures with amazing zoom! Though only con is that battery life is terrible, so I had to buy rechargeable lithium batteries. I needed a good camera for low light and compact size as I go to concerts and other events and this camera does the job for me! The color is really nice as well.

Reviews.Title: WOW, what a camera!!!
Reviews.Author: B. A. Speller "Dickens"
Reviews.Content: I have had cameras in the past using the usual cartridge, roll film, canister, etc. including 4x5 plate formats, twin lens reflex, SLR, etc., and more recent early digital cameras.  The Nikon L610 is the first digital I have owned that feels like a more substantial SLR when holding it.  Today, most digital cameras are not much bigger than a pack of cigarettes, and thinner.  They are awkward to hold, and if your hands are bigger than medium size, the challenge to keep fingers off of unwanted feature buttons can be daunting.  The L610 has what I will call a vertical 'bulge' on the right side, which is perfect for your grip.  The shape of the top of the camera is, on first look, very unusual, and then you recognize that it provides some additional ergonomics that make your left hand grip better, and which keeps those errant fingers above the lens, and away from the viewing screen. And when you deploy the flash, the left hand still remains clear.  The viewing screen is a terrific 3" wide, which doesn't seem like much, until you compose your photo on it.  It is BIG.  The top of the camera is super user friendly.  The power button is in a perfect location, the shutter is easily found without looking for it every time you take a shot, and the zoom control (part of the shutter assembly) is also 'intuitive'.Menu features are very simple to use, even if you don't bother to read any of the instructions that come with the camera.  I have not used the movie feature extensively yet, so I have some learning to catch up on with respect to the sound recording level adjustments.  However, the video was simple to use, and playback likewise was intuitive.  By the way, we shot inside with available light, and the quality of the video was excellent!  We really didn't take the time to do a decent test of the sound level, but what we did record was clear.The package comes with a USB cable, and a video cable, a camera strap, and two AA batteries.  There are plenty of accessories available, but I limited myself to a 16 GB SDHC card, a Case Logic camera case, and a set of four rechargeable batteries with charger.  The price of the camera, plus the noted accessories was a total of nine dollars more than the lowest price for just the camera that I found anywhere else.One final note:  Nikon engineers have a home run with this camera.  The ergonomics are first rate - for you Industrial Engineers out there, this model is a case study in human factors engineering.  For the rest of us, this camera is at the perfect price point for new digital camera users, and is a welcome high quality addition to the more seasoned user's camera bag.

Reviews.Title: Battery eater
Reviews.Author: Amazon Buyer
Reviews.Content: Beware.  It eats batteries very fast.  A set of Enelope rechargeable batteries, fully charged, lasts for a max of 160 minutes of video capture with my Canon and Kodak cameras.  This one only has a max of 57 minutes.

Reviews.Title: Not good for action shots
Reviews.Author: J. Turner "ottermonkey"
Reviews.Content: As a mother of a toddler, I was reeled in by the Nikon Commercials with Ashton Kutcher taking perfect action shots. I new a Nikon Coolpix was what I needed to get shots of my son. I got this camera on Christmas eve and just took it back to Best Buy today to exchange it.Good things:*Tons of unique features ( color editing, skin texture editing, panoramic, HD videos, etc)*Gorgeous HD videos WITH ability to zoom while filming*pocket size*beautiful shots of STILL objects*excellent zoomNot so great:*NOT FOR MOVING SUBJECTS!!! ( pets, children)*not very user friendly*reviewing pictures is very frustrating as you have to start from the beginning every time. Even after you edit a shot, you can't compare it to the original shot without shutting off the camera, turning it back on and scrolling through ALL of your pictures.If you enjoy simple editing of your photos and do not intend to used this for any action shots, you will probably love this camera. For anyone intending to use this for anything that moves, I would keep looking. I tried adjusting the shutter speeds, the sports setting, and even the "continuous shots" mode without any luck. It is just not a good camera for pets or children. Guess I nee the model Ashton had...

Reviews.Title: No joy with battery life..
Reviews.Author: blackhawk
Reviews.Content: My Canon 100HS elph broke with dreaded lens error.  Decided to switch to Nikon.  Was impressed with my mom's S9100 but knew it went thru batteries quickly and wanted flexibility of AA batteries.  My older A610 used 4 AA batteries and wouldn't have to change them for a month.  Now we're lucky if we get 50 shots before changing the batteries with L610.  I've taken several videos and they all end with a 'Battery Exhausted' screen!  This camera has a difficult time with auto focus when shooting indoors, making it a little frustrating.  Outdoors shooting is quick and a lot easier, until it's time to replace the batteries.  Although I really like Canon's displays and camera software better, I can't justify buying another Canon that won't last until they fix the lens error problems.

Reviews.Title: not rechargable
Reviews.Author: Mary A Gilbert
Reviews.Content: When I purchased this camera I didn't realize it came with regular AA batteries not rechargeable ones, that was disappointingAlso it did not come with a memory card either so that was disappointing, it does take really nice photos though

Reviews.Title: We Got this Because we were having a baby
Reviews.Author: Nolalita
Reviews.Content: We read all the reviews and thought this would be a good general camera for taking pictures of a baby (our old camera had a shutter speed that was too slow to catch a smile).  Our prior camera took 2A batteries, and I didn't mind having to change them.  I preferred that rather than having to charge a dead battery.  We bought the faster memory storage that was suggested by one review.  However, the batteries on this are just horrible.  We probably couldn't take 10 pictures without the batteries dying!  We can't even take video because the battery situation is so bad.  Just horrible.  All of the pictures are blurry.  This thing is a total waste.  We are so disillusioned that we haven't gotten anything else.  We just take pictures and video of our new precious bundle on our android phones :-(

Reviews.Title: Easy
Reviews.Author: chriso
Reviews.Content: Small, light weight and easy to use. Not a point and shoot, but a point, focus and shoot. Which is good if you're trying to catch something actiony. You can just focus where you think things will hapen focus, (Button half down) and click when the action is there, Pictures are fine, and at the time it was pretty highly rated in Consumer Reports.

Reviews.Title: Deceived
Reviews.Author: Oscar
Reviews.Content: This camera has a big problem. It uses batteries too fast because the led screen, which wouldn't be a problem if it would accept rechargeable batteries. It doesn't take them because rechargeable batteries do not reach 1.5 volts when fully loaded and the camera demands such voltage. I don't have the time to exchange for something better. Never more Nikon. I've wasted my money.

Reviews.Title: Nice, Functional, Easy-To-Use Camera
Reviews.Author: John R. Thompson
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera after much thought.  I had just ruined my Sony W-170 camera after falling into Tensleep Creek (Wyoming) with it.  I'm not made of money, so, after reading numerous reviews, comparing features and prices, I settled with the Nikon L610.  VERY PLEASED.  I bought a bundle with camera, case, memory card, batteries, tripod, strap, and I forget what else.I was concerned with battery life, so I purchased 12 Energizer Ultimate Lithium 9x batteries.  Took nearly 200 photos with no battery issues, or, for that matter, no issues at all.  The ONLY thing that I dislike is its seemingly long (1-2 seconds?) lapse to focus after using the telephoto.  No big deal.  The photos are crystal clear, colors are spot on.  And...it is easy to use.  I just use Auto Mode and set  the ISO to 200.  Works for me!!Bottom line: If you want a reasonably priced camera that is easy to use and delivers great photos, look no further.  Just be sure to buy the better batteries.  So far, I have still the original two batteries in the unit.  I put it into service in late August 2013.Update:  It is now April 19, 2014....I still have the original 2 Energizer Ultimate Lithium batteries in this unit.  This morning, they went dead, after taking 3 pictures.  So....I don't think that is bad at all for battery/camera performance.  8 months of use.  The one dissatisfaction is the time it takes to refocus when using the telephoto, and, sometimes, in closeup shots, the image is blurry.  Neither is a big deal for me....

Reviews.Title: Good but not great.
Reviews.Author: KK
Reviews.Content: Takes great still pictures anything moving has a blur. You also need to use extended life batteries, regular battery only last for about 12 pictures.

Reviews.Title: Camera takes bad pictures
Reviews.Author: E. Fambrough
Reviews.Content: The ISO sensor is either bad or too small on this camera, so most pictures are blurry in auto mode.  The subject's eyes can even turn out blurry when they blink!  I spent a lot of time with Nikon customer service in trying to resolve this year.  A lot of time on the phone describing the problem and I had to submit several photos showing my problems.  They would send me the usual fixes and every time I would show them that camera was faulty.  After much back and forth, Nikon's customer service requested I send it in.  They said that they updated the software and it should work properly.While it was just a little better, I still would have to manually adjust the ISO.  Finally, at my daughter's Christmas program this week, I setup the camera to make sure I had the correct settings.  When my daughter came out, I tried to take a picture and the camera would just turn off.  I turned it back on and tried again, same result.  I believe the batteries may have been low (although there was no indicator about a low battery)...they were ok for a picture in auto mode (again, all blurry) but the camera would turn off when ISO was adjusted.Needless to say, this camera is going in the trash.  I just spent a ton of money on a competitor's camera.  I know that Nikon has great DSLRs but their point and shoot market is horrible.

Reviews.Title: not a bad camara
Reviews.Author: Charles V.
Reviews.Content: very good. but had to go on the internet to get the instructions on how it works! 252 pages!!!! lots of printing..

Reviews.Title: 5,000 pictures: Works like new!
Reviews.Author: G-mann
Reviews.Content: I take photos for my carreer. The picture quality is great, it can be set on auto-mode, or you can adjust settings for each picture/environment. It is durable: I have dropped/bumped/abused it and it keeps going. I also appreciate it's small size: it fits in a pocket, unlike the bigger, heavier cameras. Good value for the price.

Reviews.Title: Exactly what I wanted.
Reviews.Author: Ruthann Daniels
Reviews.Content: This camera was great!  I ordered it for use at a concert where flash was not allowed, and it took great pics.  The 14X zoom was a boon!  So easy to transfer photos to my computer, too.  Lithium batteries work best.  Camera is small enough not to be a burden at a concert.

Reviews.Title: Nikon Coolpix L610 Digital Camera
Reviews.Author: Rawn A. Wallgren
Reviews.Content: We love the camera.  It's easy to use and the 16 megapixals make the pictures stunningly sharp.  I also love the 14 powere digital zoom.  I can get as close to subjects as I can with my digital SLR and 300 mm lens.

Reviews.Title: Nikon cool pix
Reviews.Author: fish247
Reviews.Content: The camera is way beyond my expatitions for a point and shoot. It is very simple to operate and fits my dry bag in the boat. Has features many high dollar cameras do not have.

Reviews.Title: Vacation pictures were the best!
Reviews.Author: blueyes
Reviews.Content: Just took this on vacation,  in the Blue Ridge foothills.  I took some great pics in the mountains.  It functioned very well, the features are easy to use, you really can just point and shoot.

Reviews.Title: GREAT
Reviews.Author: carlosr
Reviews.Content: REALLY MORE THAT I EXPECT IT NIKON IS ALWAYS A WARRANTY AND THIS IS NOT A EXCEPTION REALLY EASY TO USE ANDGREAT ZOOM LIKE A PRO!!!

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera
Reviews.Author: Griff
Reviews.Content: This camera produces sharp images, is easy to use, and small enough to fit in my jacket pocket.  Very well made.  I suggest you buy a battery charger with lithium batteries.  I did and battery life is not a problem, as it has been with some of the other reviewers.

Reviews.Title: Really good camera for the price!
Reviews.Author: Gretchen L. Horn "Gretchen the gardener"
Reviews.Content: So far I really like it ,especially at the price.  My only complaint really isn't about this camera.  I just wish someone would make an inexpensive .digital with a viewfinder.  My 5 year old Canon had one but  no one has  now.  Pictures in bright sun just more difficult.  Very crisp and good telephoto though.  Also Nikon should really add just a little to the price and include lithium batteries as you are going to need them.  I am a fan of AA batteries but get lithium.  Nice size camera for me as I like to know I have a camera, not a credit card in my hands.

Reviews.Title: Outstanding Camera
Reviews.Author: ValueShopper "Mrs. T"
Reviews.Content: Just received my new Nikon COOLPIX L610 and so far I am thrilled.  The red is a candy apple red..beautiful!  Only taken a few pictures but look forward to using and exploring all the fine features that I was looking for in a Nikon.  Must mention the price was outstanding as I really searched and seached to get the most for my money.  Service and delivery was outstanding.

Reviews.Title: Love this camera!!!
Reviews.Author: oceangoer03
Reviews.Content: I had a Nikon Coolpix years ago and loved it but it was stolen. Then I had a Canon and it was adequate. I received this Nikon Coolpix L610 for Christmas 2012 and absolutely positively love it! The pictures are incredibly clear and crisp, and the multiple picture settings are very easy to use. I like the continuous shot feature for kids/animals where they move a lot. The zoom capability is excellent! I'm a huge fan of the grip - it feels substantial in your hand and you can hold it easily without fear of dropping it, unlike the little flat cameras that can fit in a pocket. This camera cannot fit in a pocket, except for maybe a man's cargo short pocket. Be sure to buy Energizer Lithium batteries - I'm reading reviews that the camera "eats" batteries - this is only because you're using regular alkaline batteries that are not specifically geared toward electronics. Change the setting so the camera knows you're using lithium. The lithium batteries should give you at least 200 pictures!

Reviews.Title: WOW
Reviews.Author: jahornby
Reviews.Content: its heavier than the L19 i was trying to get, but unbelievable pictures quality.  i haven't printed any pics yet, but on the computer they look as good as my old professional 35mm used to do.  its a bit complicated with all the possible settings but just leave it on the easy setting and you get great pics.  on video it also does a great job, not as easy to hold steady as a regular camcorder grip, but a tripod should solve that.  does suck the life out of the batteries on video, but then its not really a video recorder so for a little now and then video its good.  as a long time photographer (2 years professionally) i highly recommend this camera for anyone that wants great pictures, keep extra batteries and be prepared to be  truly amazed at the quality.

Reviews.Title: I really like this camera
Reviews.Author: C. Palacios
Reviews.Content: I've had this camera for about a month now and kinda love it. It's a point and shoot so the ease of use is great. The pictures are really high quality and there are lots of presets to choose from. You can also do some manual settings if you know a little about what you are doing. It takes great close up shots with the macro feature. The zoom is decent. It's surprisingly light weight. The part I love the best is that you can use any AA batteries. Lithium lasts longer but it's great to know that in a pinch you can use pretty much any of them. I hate having to charge batteries for cameras so it's great that this doesn't have one. I have noticed sometimes it's a bit difficult to get actions shots that aren't blurry. but they are action shots so that's a challenge anyway. I love that you can do continuous shots too. That's great. The menu is pretty easy to navigate too. I'd recommend this for anyone who doesn't wanna fuss with heavy equipment. It's so light it's not a pain to carry around. I would recommend getting a good fast memory card for it.

Reviews.Title: Great except for.....
Reviews.Author: Mel "Mel"
Reviews.Content: I really like the camera except for two issues, I goes through batteries pretty fast.  I'm shooting outside in the winter and hopefully it will be better in warmer weather.  The other thing is I really miss a view finder, I didn't think I would but now I'm sorry I bought a camera without one.

Reviews.Title: This is a great pocket camera
Reviews.Author: Jesus Resendiz Rodriguez "CHUYTIME"
Reviews.Content: This camera is great with a good quality and it's small for travel and recomended to my sons and my family

Reviews.Title: Lots of Camera for the money
Reviews.Author: tim weisse
Reviews.Content: I like this camera because it has some bulk to it.  I''m just not comfortable with one of those tiny little point and shoot cameras.  I do alot of travel photography and by having a little more bulk in the body,, you can have a nice 14X and up optical zoom. This is 14X and with the auto sabilization, the pictures are criso and clear. Although I do not do a great deal of close up photography,, this camera seems to have alittle trouble holding focus for close ups.  Of course the problem is eliminated if you take the time to use the macro mode in the camera.  I bought the silver modeal and it looks great with the black contrast of the textured grip.  There are no options for manual settings, but this camera seems to have it all covered with great features and a large supply of shooting modes.  High def video is great.  I do miss being able to throw a background out of focus.

Reviews.Title: Way above expectations
Reviews.Author: Er
Reviews.Content: To be fair I bought this camera, without many expectations and as a last minute low-cost gift.It's way-way above expectations to be honest. The photo quality is AWESOME and it has some really nice features.I would recommend it to anyone!

Reviews.Title: Great camera and great price
Reviews.Author: isaacalan7
Reviews.Content: I use this for proffessional use and at home. This is the first camera in a long time that I'm happy with.

Reviews.Title: I love my Nikon Coolpix L610 Picture quality and features are excellent.
Reviews.Author: H M Saxena
Reviews.Content: Superb picture quality combined with all the advanced features in an easy to operate camera are like a wish came true. I only wish it also had a rechargeable battery.

Reviews.Title: The best little camera
Reviews.Author: B
Reviews.Content: So far so good.  Have to try some night and action shots.  Then ask me.  But for ordinary pictures, it performs better than others that I've had, like the Sony cameras.

Reviews.Title: I had higher expectations for this camera, but it still takes nice photos
Reviews.Author: Russ A Carpenter
Reviews.Content: My first compact digital camera was a Coolpix 880 way back when, and it took great pictures, and had nice features.  For this particular camera, I was looking fo something more simple (since I have a D-SLR now), but still takes crisp photos.  So far, I've been somewhat disappointed in the ease-of-use factor for this camera.  For example, you must pop up the flash for it to work, even when setting the flash to "auto" on the easy setting.  Where is the automation there??  I like that the flash is not built into the body (does a better job that way), but really, how hard can it be to automate it to pop up when I set it as such?  And it also seemed to take a long time for the flash to re-cycle.  As in several seconds (on fresh batteries), so I was also disappointed there.  But as for image quality, it does deliver on that point.  Even in lower light, the images have nice clarity (when you keep the ISO set to 200 or lower especially).  The overall feature set is somewhat limited, and there isn't much in the way of manual controls, but then again, that isn't what I was after when I bought this (that's why you need a D-SLR).  I'm using Lithium batteries for this, as recommended by others, and so far I'm still on my first set of those after more than 150 pictures and some video.  Speaking of the video, I haven't done much shooting with that yet, so the jusy is still out on that quality.To further update, as was the case with my original Coolpix, the battery door stop latching after a minor drop (I really mean minor... about a 2 foot drop onto a tile floor).  I suppose it hit the right spot with the wrong force to break whatever little tab holds the door closed.  Now the Scotch Tape latch must be used, as because Nikon wouldn't fix it for free (they wanted $80 or $90 to fix it, and I only paid $130).  So I was pretty disappointed, and now have learned not to buy Nikon compact cameras anymore.

Reviews.Title: Great camera!
Reviews.Author: TONI FERNANDEZ
Reviews.Content: Wow the pixels are great. The zoom allows you to take beautiful pictures. It took a little while to figure out how to view my pictures, but I love this camera

Reviews.Title: Husband loves it.
Reviews.Author: Barbara Bunjiovianna
Reviews.Content: My husband requested this for Christmas.  He is real happy with the low light pictures, they come out real clear.

Reviews.Title: Nikon Coolpix Camera
Reviews.Author: Jess
Reviews.Content: This product arrived on time and in perfect condition. It is a very nice camera and the pictures turn out sharp and very clear. The colors are bright and vivid, and one of the only downsides is that it is difficult to take motion pictures. Other than that, this camera has many nice features and works like a charm.

Reviews.Title: Good Camera
Reviews.Author: creole
Reviews.Content: The picure quality is very good for a low price camera. A good camera for a point and shoot, very light.

Reviews.Title: it eats batteries for lunch
Reviews.Author: e h meltzer
Reviews.Content: the worst thing by far is that this thing eats batteries like there's no tomorrow.  Even lithium batteries relative to other cameras.  My last camera would take thousands of shots before giving up on lithiums, this one will eat them after about 200 and that's if you don't keep it on except to take the shot.  Heaven forbid using this in cold weather or if you fiddle with it for a while.Another problem is that beyond the most basic functions, there's probably a lot this camera can do that isn't obvious.  The user manual [printed version] only outlines the most basic functions but you have to go to the digital manual, which is much more voluminous to get much more information.  For those of us without mobile devices beyond a laptop that's a pain.I would not recommend anyone purchase this turkey.  You can do better elsewhere and I may buy another, better reviewed camera just to rid myself of this burdern.

Reviews.Title: Disappointed
Reviews.Author: C. Bramlett
Reviews.Content: Being a pro-photog, I bought this camera as a vacation camera since I wouldn't dare take my livelihood to Disney World. I'm a loyal Nikon consumer and really expected more from this. I did about as much research as I could the 3 weeks before we left and the reviews I had covered led me to this one. Focus is insanely slow! For being a 16mp camera, and shooting at highest res, my images are unacceptably pixelated. And shooting with less than sunlight apparently overtaxes the camera.Yes, you will need high-quality lithium batteries, but that should go without saying for today's digital cameras. Let's just say that my old Kodak P-n-S that's about 6 yrs old takes better pics than this one. Nikon, I'm really disappointed.

Reviews.Title: Blurry pictures
Reviews.Author: Larry E. Eaton
Reviews.Content: I got very blurry pictures.  I did not think the 14x zoom was as good as it should be.  It was to late for me to return to Amazon, so I contacted Nikon.  I thought the camera was defective.  After emailing back and forth with them, they basically told me it was my fault and I should read the manual.  I had read the manual and had all my settings where they should be, before I had contacted them.  Bottom line I will not buy a Nikon product again, due to poor customer service.

Reviews.Title: Battery Sucker!
Reviews.Author: my 2 cents "my 2 cents"
Reviews.Content: I wanted a camera to take product shots for my website.  I wrote to Nikon and Canon since everyone says they are THE BEST in the camera industry.  I liked what Nikon had to say and I purchased this model at their recommendation. I put in the batteries it came with and took maybe 10 shots before I got my first battery notification.  I turned it off and waited a couple minutes and tried again..this time a couple shots and a battery message.  I put in NEW batteries from a NEW package and only a few shots later..battery message.  I changed the batteries again..same thing.  I use a light tent and no flash so I find the batteries draining so quickly a bit ridiculous.  I contacted Nikon and they asked me to make sure I had the battery setting right and was using alkaline batteries.  Check and Check.  So they recommended Service.  Because I only had it a few days I opted to return it for a replacement.  But THEN I began reading the latest reviews and I see I'm not the only person to have this issue.  I need a good reliable camera that doesn't go through a 12-pack of batteries every time I need to shoot 20 pics!  I contacted Amazon and they sent me a pre-paid label so I can return it when it arrives.  It's really too bad because the close-ups were amazing and just what I needed!  In fact, it was the reason I bought the camera.
